theory: The concept of 'nakama' established in Episode 43 becomes the philosophical foundation of the Straw Hat Pirates and influences every major arc. Luffy's declaration 'Nami, you are my friend!' sets the precedent that the crew fights not for treasure or glory, but for each other. This moment foreshadows future arcs where Luffy will go to extreme lengths to rescue or support his crewmates (Enies Lobby for Robin, Whole Cake Island for Sanji, etc.).

theory: Nami's character arc in the Arlong Park arc, particularly her breakdown and subsequent rescue by Luffy, serves as the template for how Oda writes emotional character arcs throughout One Piece. The formula of: character suffering in isolation → refusing help → emotional breaking point → crew intervention → dramatic rescue became the blueprint for Robin (Enies Lobby), Sanji (Whole Cake Island), and others.

theory: Nezumi's corruption and his partnership with Arlong represents the series' first major exploration of systemic injustice within the World Government. His revenge by reporting Luffy for a bounty ironically validates Luffy as a threat to corrupt authority. This theme of 'official' forces being as bad or worse than pirates continues throughout the series, particularly with the Celestial Dragons and corrupt Marine officials.

theory: Luffy's quote 'Of course I can't use a sword! And I can't navigate! And I can't cook! And I can't lie! I know I need help to accomplish my dream!' is one of the most important lines in One Piece as it establishes that strength comes from acknowledging weakness and relying on others. This directly contrasts with typical shonen protagonists who must be self-sufficient, and defines what makes the Straw Hat crew special.

theory: The blood on Nami's pen represents not just physical suffering but the cost of her dreams being corrupted. She dreamed of mapping the world, but Arlong forced her to use that dream as a tool of oppression. Luffy destroying the maps isn't just freeing her physically - it's giving her permission to dream freely again. This theme of 'corrupted dreams' appears throughout One Piece with various characters.
